results.abstract: Bob Sweeney essay on his young son's breakfast conversations about school and his second-grade teacher; drawing (M)
results.snippet: MY son Ryan is 7, a second grader at Brookside School in Ossining. His home away from home for almost six hours each school day is Mr. Horan's class, Room 9. As a veteran high school counselor, I know what lies ahead for him, the pressures he and...
results.lead_paragraph: MY son Ryan is 7, a second grader at Brookside School in Ossining. His home away from home for almost six hours each school day is Mr. Horan's class, Room 9. As a veteran high school counselor, I know what lies ahead for him, the pressures he and those who teach him will face. As a rookie parent, I can't help wonder what the hours at school are like for him -- whether he enjoys them, whether he has friends, even what he's thinking and learning. If I ask him, ''How was school?'' I get the standard reflexive reply, ''O.K.'' If I try again, wording the question more craftily to get beyond a one-word answer, I may get a sentence, and then, it's not always complete. I am resigned to the fact Ryan will let me know what I need to know on his terms and when he is ready.

results.abstract: Arab Family Day at Queens Museum of Art draws New York City's Arab-American students, and many show pain of war in Iraq; photo (M)

headline.main: A Single Alphabet Bridges Children's Two Cultures

results.snippet: Arab Family Day at the Queens Museum of Art yesterday was billed as an invitation to members of New York City's Arab-American communities to come together for ''a positive moment during difficult times.''    And it was clear that for many...
results.lead_paragraph: Arab Family Day at the Queens Museum of Art yesterday was billed as an invitation to members of New York City's Arab-American communities to come together for ''a positive moment during difficult times.'' And it was clear that for many Arab-American students who attended, these are difficult times indeed. They have grown weary of watching distressing images from war-torn Iraq, many of them news photographs and videotape depicting young faces resembling their own, but streaked with fear and grief.

results.abstract: Col James D Halsell Jr of Air Force, astronaut who will be in charge of planning resumption of shuttle flights, asserts that NASA had failed to see trend in shedding of foam from external tank, despite similar incident a few months before Columbia accident, because agency thought it had solved problem years earlier; photo (M)

headline.main: Official Says NASA Erred on Tank Problem

results.snippet: The astronaut who will be in charge of planning the resumption of shuttle flights said today that NASA had failed to see a trend in the shedding of foam from the external tank, despite a similar incident a few months before the Columbia accident,...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronaut who will be in charge of planning the resumption of shuttle flights said today that NASA had failed to see a trend in the shedding of foam from the external tank, despite a similar incident a few months before the Columbia accident, because the agency thought that it had solved the problem years earlier. If the Columbia had returned home safely, the shedding of its foam at liftoff would have been treated as a top-level safety problem, because it so closely followed similar shedding from the Atlantis's external tank in October 2002, and the two incidents together would have been recognized as a ''generic'' problem, said the official, Col. James D. Halsell Jr. of the Air Force.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    War News Summary   B2    Thai Crackdown on Drugs Causes High Death Toll  An extraordinary campaign of government-approved killings is under way in Thailand -- a crackdown on drug dealers that has taken an average of 30 lives...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 War News Summary B2 Thai Crackdown on Drugs Causes High Death Toll An extraordinary campaign of government-approved killings is under way in Thailand -- a crackdown on drug dealers that has taken an average of 30 lives a day. The death toll equals that of the carnage in East Timor in 1999, and has drawn outrage from human rights groups. A3

results.abstract: Investigators say most of recovered U-shaped panels from leading edge of space shuttle Columbia's left wing were split along middle; believe left wing was opened up to superheated gases as shuttle tried to return to Earth, but they are still uncertain about chain of events leading up to disaster; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Findings Deemed Significant, but Inconclusive

results.snippet: Investigators said today that most of the recovered U-shaped panels from the leading edge of the Columbia's left wing had been split along the middle. They said the finding was significant, but they did not know what it meant.     Experts say they...

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and MATTHEW L. WALD

results.lead_paragraph: Investigators said today that most of the recovered U-shaped panels from the leading edge of the Columbia's left wing had been split along the middle. They said the finding was significant, but they did not know what it meant. Experts say they believe that the left wing was opened up to superheated gases, probably at the leading edge, as the shuttle tried to return to earth on Feb. 1. Their operative theory is that the cause of the breach was a strike by debris on liftoff. But nine weeks into the investigation, they say they are still uncertain about the chain of events, and new findings like the one today about the reinforced carbon-carbon wing panels merely added to the mystery.

results.abstract: Peter M Nichols Taking the Children reviews of movies What a Girl Wants, The Core and Head of State (S)

headline.main: Girl's Hunt for Dad Brings Smiles to Stiff Lips

results.snippet: What a Girl Wants  Amanda Bynes, Colin Firth, Anna Chancellor, Christina Cole, Oliver James, Kelly Preston, Jonathan Pryce  Directed by Dennie Gordon  PG 105 minutes      Reared in Manhattan, 17-year-old Daphne (Ms. Bynes) longs for the English...
results.lead_paragraph: What a Girl Wants Amanda Bynes, Colin Firth, Anna Chancellor, Christina Cole, Oliver James, Kelly Preston, Jonathan Pryce Directed by Dennie Gordon PG 105 minutes Reared in Manhattan, 17-year-old Daphne (Ms. Bynes) longs for the English father she's never met, Lord Dashwood (Mr. Firth). Daphne is the product of Dashwood's liaison with an American rock singer, Libby (Ms. Preston), in the North African desert. Back in England, Libby met with disapproval from Dashwood's conventionally snooty family and went home to New York.

results.abstract: NASA says two astronauts who will take over International Space Station should be able to conduct substantial research despite absence of third crew member; photo of Russian astronaut Yuri I Malenchenko and American Edward T Lu; two-person crews will run station until space shuttle fleet is back up (S)

headline.main: Leaner Space Crew Still Plans Research

results.snippet: The crew that will head to the International Space Station next week should be able to conduct a substantial amount of research despite being reduced by a third, NASA officials said today.    The Russian astronaut, Yuri I. Malenchenko, and his...
results.lead_paragraph: The crew that will head to the International Space Station next week should be able to conduct a substantial amount of research despite being reduced by a third, NASA officials said today. The Russian astronaut, Yuri I. Malenchenko, and his American partner, Edward T. Lu, are to take up residence on the station at the end of April and replace a three-man crew that has been aboard since October.

results.abstract: Harold W Gehman Jr, chairman of independent commission investigating Columbia shuttle disaster, suggests panel may recommend use of new construction materials for future spacecraft; holds that in particular, panel may suggest use of other material, possibly titanium, for inner structure rather than aluminum currently used; some scientists believe time would be better spent developing durable and in-flight repairable thermal protection system to replace cumbersome heat-shedding tiles (M)

headline.main: Inquiry Focuses on Skeletons of Space Shuttles

results.snippet: When the space shuttle Columbia first flew, 22 years ago this month, much attention was paid to its skin, which was made of a new type of heat-resistant tile. Few people focused on its skeleton, made of a much more familiar material -- lightweight,...
results.lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Columbia first flew, 22 years ago this month, much attention was paid to its skin, which was made of a new type of heat-resistant tile. Few people focused on its skeleton, made of a much more familiar material -- lightweight, inexpensive aluminum. Now, in hindsight, investigators are postulating whether the aluminum played a central role in Columbia's destruction. When the shuttle's thermal protection system began to fail, the aluminum skeleton was unforgiving. It not only melted, but burned.

results.abstract: Soyuz rocket carrying American astronaut, Edward Lu, and Russian cosmonaut blasts off for international space station on mission intended to keep space exploration going despite Columbia space shuttle tragedy; rocket blasts off from Baikonur, Kazakhstan (S)

headline.main: American and Russian Blast Off Into Space

results.snippet: A Soyuz rocket carrying an American astronaut and Russian cosmonaut blasted off for the international space station today on a mission intended to keep space exploration going despite the Columbia space shuttle tragedy.    From deep in the Kazakh...
results.lead_paragraph: A Soyuz rocket carrying an American astronaut and Russian cosmonaut blasted off for the international space station today on a mission intended to keep space exploration going despite the Columbia space shuttle tragedy. From deep in the Kazakh steppe, the 130-foot Russian rocket, the latest version of the world's longest-serving manned spacecraft, soared into space at 7:54 a.m. on its way to the station, some 220 miles above Earth. Shortly after liftoff, the rocket was safely in orbit, space officials said.

results.abstract: Sean O'Keefe, NASA administrator, says one of greatest challenges for NASA managers when space shuttles start flying again will be finding better ways to anticipate problems tha can compromise safety; says theme emerging in investigation of Columbia disaster is how well agency identifies potential problems; photo of search for Columbia debris near Douglass, Texas (M)

headline.main: NASA Official Urges a Focus on Potential Problems

results.snippet: One of the greatest challenges for NASA managers when space shuttles start flying again will be finding better ways to anticipate problems that can compromise safety, the leader of the space agency said today.    Sean O'Keefe, the National...
results.lead_paragraph: One of the greatest challenges for NASA managers when space shuttles start flying again will be finding better ways to anticipate problems that can compromise safety, the leader of the space agency said today. Sean O'Keefe, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration administrator, said a theme emerging in the investigation of the Columbia disaster was how well the agency identifies potential problems.

results.abstract: Crew on board International Space Station for last five months is eager for return home on May 3 now that replacement crew has arrived; crewmen--Capt Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit of US and Nikolai M Budarin, Russian flight engineer--will return in Russian Soyuz spacecraft that was their emergency lifeboat (M)

headline.main: Station's Crew Eager for Trip Back to Earth This Weekend

results.snippet: The crewmen who have manned the International Space Station for five months said today that they would miss it but were eager to head home now that their replacements had arrived.    The crew of two Americans -- Capt. Kenneth D. Bowersox of the Navy,...
results.lead_paragraph: The crewmen who have manned the International Space Station for five months said today that they would miss it but were eager to head home now that their replacements had arrived. The crew of two Americans -- Capt. Kenneth D. Bowersox of the Navy, the station commander, and Dr. Donald R. Pettit, science officer -- and a Russian flight engineer, Nikolai M. Budarin, is to return to Earth this weekend after an extended stay caused by the Columbia accident.

results.abstract: Panel investigating breakup of shuttle Columbia says it is still devising tests that it hopes will determine cause; members try to lower expectations about how definitive those tests might be; back away from what looked like conclusion that object observed on radar floating away from shuttle in its second day in orbit was T-seal; explosive bolts used to separate solid rocket boosters from shuttle assembly will be studied along with foam insulation as possible damage mechanism (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Panel Devising Tests to Determine Cause of Crash

results.snippet: Nearly three months after the breakup of the shuttle Columbia, the road ahead for investigators is beginning to look longer.    They said today that they were still devising tests that they hoped would help them determine the cause of the breakup,...
results.lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after the breakup of the shuttle Columbia, the road ahead for investigators is beginning to look longer. They said today that they were still devising tests that they hoped would help them determine the cause of the breakup, and the investigators tried to lower expectations about how definitive those might be.
